results.title: Living in a metropolis: Greater New York
results.creator_credit: Louis De Rochemont and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
This film describes New York City; population 9,000,000 (1949). Aerial views of the city and harbour, its office buildings etc show briefly its general appearance. A gateway to the United States from the East, it is a terminus for shipping, a railroad centre and has three airports. Film also includes glimpses of Park Avenue, Harlem, Chinatown, the housing projects, subways, bridges, tunnels, the food markets, restaurants, the banks on Wall Street, the garment industry and departmental stores, Central Park, Coney Island and Times Square.
results.title_for_label: Living in a metropolis: Greater New York
results.creator_credit_for_label: Louis De Rochemont and Louis de Rochemont Associates

results.title: Highlands of the Andes
results.creator_credit: Jules Bucher, United World Films and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
A description of the Andes of Peru and the mineral resources of the area. Shows the people working in the gold, silver and copper mines, also farmers cultivating the poor, rocky soil.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jules Bucher, United World Films and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.description:

results.title: Water for dry land
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”
The dependence of man upon his supply of water. The transformation of desert lands by controlling water supply is shown.

results.title: Mountain farmers: Switzerland
results.creator_credit: John Ferno and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
This film describes the life and characteristics of the mountain valleys of Switzerland, including the Emmenthal (German), the Engadine (Italian), and western Switzerland (French). All available land is used , being divided for the most part into small holdings of approximately fifteen acres. Water power is a natural resource, providing electricity. Crops vary in each region, as do habits and customs. Co-operatives flourish. We are shown the farm and family life of farmer Hofer, a typical farmer of the region, including glimpses of work and play, in summer and winter; the daily lives of these mountain farmers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Ferno and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.description:

Crops vary in each region, as do habits and customs. Co-operatives flourish. We are shown the farm and family life of farmer Hofer, a typical farmer of the region, including glimpses of work and play, in summer and winter; the daily lives of these mountain farmers.

results.title: Adobe village: valley of Mexico
results.creator_credit: Joseph Brun, Louis De Rochemont and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Built on a swamp at a high altitude, modern Mexico City was built on the Aztec city of Teotihuacan by the Spanish who invaded the region. This documentary follows a typical Mexican family in an adobe village, weaving serapes, harvesting corn and raising cattles, sheep, horses, goats and donkeys. Discusses their diet, education, work and family life. Also attempts to explain how Aztec Indian culture has ‘blended’ with Spanish culture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joseph Brun, Louis De Rochemont and Louis de Rochemont Associates

Discusses their diet, education, work and family life. Also attempts to explain how Aztec Indian culture has ‘blended’ with Spanish culture.

results.title: Farms and towns of Slovakia: a Danube River country
results.creator_credit: Ronald Craigen and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Illustrates many aspects of peasant life in Slovakia (Czechoslovakia). Traditional methods of cultivation and harvesting crops are described, but the film shows the changes in methods which are occurring. The village pictured in the film is in the Tatra Mountains, in the northern part of Slovakia.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Ronald Craigen and Louis de Rochemont Associates

results.creator_credit: Leroy Phelps and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Shows the life-style and occupations of the Indian people of Guatemala, including the felling of mahogany trees in the forests and farming on the high plateaux. Starting from the east in the Peten lowlands the film proceeds north-westwards across Central America, focusing attention on features which are typical of the geography of the Peten lowlands, the central highlands, and the Pacific coastlands. It exemplifies changes in modes of life with increased altitude within this tropical area, and illustrates some of the influences of the civilization of the Mayas and of Spanish colonial rule.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Leroy Phelps and Louis de Rochemont Associates

results.title: East to west
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Dramatised documentary written and presented by Bill Peach. Edward John Eyre was the first white man to journey across the Nullabour Plain from the east coast to the west coast. He had originally organised and lead an expedition, beginning in Adelaide, that aimed to travel north through Australia’s centre. This attempt was hindered by mirages that prohibited him from finding a break in a series of lakes that would provide access to the north. Defeated by the desert yet determined not to return to Adelaide as a failure, he decided to attempt an east-west crossing that he had previously advised against. Accompanied by his friend John Baxter, his aboriginal guide Wylie, and two indigenous Australians, Eyre veered west. He persevered across the desolate and forbidding landscape, constantly searching for fresh water and shelter from the elements, as he headed for Perth. Unfortunately, Eyre and Wylie were the only two members of the group who eventually reached Perth following a tragic event that claimed the life of Baxter.
